page.title: 01Carrick Forest and Doughty
page.content:
Until 1979, these steep grassy hills were upland sheep pastures, mainly wet, soft and peaty, threaded by a single narrow moorland road rising from 200m a.s.l. to 337m in the North. The hills, though steep, are rarely craggy. There is only one inhabited dwelling, the lonely shepherd's cottage of Doughty.
Since 1979, more than half of the block - the Black Hill of Garleffin - has been planted with conifers, mainly by the Forestry Commission: but square 1 was planted on behalf of a private owner, by Scottish Woodland Owners (Commercial) Ltd.
Garleffin Fell (425m) in squares 7/8, forms the watershed between streams flowing NE to the River Girvan and those flowing SE to River Stinchar.
